INDUSTRY: Beauty and personal care, household products, food and beverage

Description: Certified Vegan: certifies that products do not contain animal products
INDUSTRY: Beauty and personal care, food and beverage

Description: Cruelty Free: certifies that products are not tested on animals
Leaping Bunny: certifies that products are not tested on animals
INDUSTRY: Beauty, personal care, and household cleaning products

Description: the product is vegan, defined as containing no animal ingredients or by-products, using no animal ingredients or by-products in the manufacturing process, and not tested on animals by any company or independent contractor.
PETA approved: Certifies products and companies that do not conduct animal testing and do not use animal-derived ingredients
Peta Cruelty Free: Certifies products and companies that do not conduct animal testing and do not use animal-derived ingredients
Vegan: certifies that products do not contain animal products
INDUSTRY: Beauty and personal care, household products, food and beverage

Description: Vegan Action: Certifies products that are free of animal products and byproducts
Vegan Society: Certifies products that are free of animal products and byproducts
Cruelty Free & Vegan: certifies that products are not tested on animals and do not contain animal products

EWG Verified products cannot contain any ingredients on EWG’s “Unacceptable” list, which includes ingredients with health, ecotoxicity and/or contamination concerns. These products must also meet EWG’s standards for ingredient disclosure on the label; products with the VERIFIED mark are made by manufacturers that have been fully transparent with EWG about that product’s ingredients, including fragrance ingredients.

Must not include ingredients with significant health concerns (e.g., carcinogens, endocrine disruptors).
Must provide full ingredient transparency, including all fragrance components.

Must avoid ingredients that EWG considers to be harmful or irritating to the skin.
Must provide adequate sun protection based on EWG’s analysis of SPF and active ingredients.

What It Is: Though EWG does not commonly provide a "VERIFIED" mark for food products, they do assess food and agricultural products for safety through their EWG Food Scores and pesticide analyses (like the Dirty Dozen list). The VERIFIED mark might apply if specific food products meet EWG’s health and safety criteria.
Criteria:

    Products must avoid harmful additives, excessive processing, and high levels of pesticides or contaminants.

Applies To: Food products (Note: This is less common and typically not a separate certification but related to EWG’s overall evaluations).

Must be free of harmful chemicals and contaminants.
Must disclose all ingredients and avoid known allergens and irritants.

Must not contain any ingredients that are on EWG’s restricted list, which includes carcinogens, endocrine disruptors, and other harmful substances.
Must fully disclose all ingredients, including those used in fragrances.
NSF/ANSI 305: certifies that personal care products contain at least 70% organic ingredients
NSF International: certifies that products meet certain health and safety standards
INDUSTRY: Food and beverage, water treatment, consumer products
NOTES:
Originally called the National Sanitation Foundation, NSF is a third-party certification that ensures human and environmental safety across several different industries.

What gets certified? Everything from drinking water and water filters, commercial foodservice equipment, nutritional supplements, private label goods, personal care items, home appliances, and clothing. Patagonia, for example, uses NSF’s Global Traceable Down Standard in their winter coats in order to ensure humane animal treatment. You can browse NSF’s directory of consumer resources here.

Description: Certified products meet standards that can reduce the environmental impact of one or more stages of the product lifecycle.
U.S. EPA Safer Choice certified products contain safer ingredients for human health and the environment.

The SCA Verified™ certification has been managed by Safe Cosmetics Australia, an independent research provider for the Australian cosmetics industry, since 2010. Safe Cosmetics Australia's aim is to improve human health by advocating for a toxic-free future.
A business which is 51 percent owned, controlled, operated, and managed by a person(s) with a disability.
A business which is 51 percent owned, controlled, operated, and managed by a veteran, but disability was not incurred during their time of service.
A business which is 51 percent owned, controlled, operated, and managed by a veteran, who sustained their disability during their time of service.
This is a designation that indicates that a company's products have been manufactured in the United States.
USDA Organic products are grown and processed according to standards addressing soil and water quality, among other factors.
workers are being paid appropriately, receiving all their legal minimum entitlements, and working in safe conditions throughout the entire supply chain.

1.Certifies for fair trade and more socially and environmentally responsible supply chains.
2.Fair For Life: Certifies products that meet fair trade and social responsibility standards
Fair Labor Association (FLA): certifies that companies meet certain labor standards
NOTES: When companies or suppliers sign on to become FLA compliant, they begin a two or three year implementation process during which they work toward bringing their supply chains into compliance with the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct, which ensures safety and health for workers. At the end of the implementation period, FLA evaluates whether the company can be considered for accreditation.

Description:
1.This is a certification program that verifies that a company's products have been produced in a socially and environmentally responsible way, with fair wages and safe working conditions for workers.
2.Products are made according to standards that promote safety, sustainability, and empowerment in the workplace.
Fair Trade Federation (FTF): Certifies fair trade organizations and companies that prioritize fair wages, safe working conditions, and sustainable production practices
Fair Trade USA: Certifies products that meet fair trade standards and support fair wages, safe working conditions, and sustainable production practices
NOTES: It’s a bit confusing because Fairtrade International and Fair Trade USA used to be the same entity; however, they separated when Fair Trade USA wanted to give large farms the opportunity to be certified as well. Fair Trade USA uses many of the same labor standards as Fair Trade International, while also including certain environmental standards like the prohibition of GMOs and toxic chemicals.

Description: Fair Wear Foundation (FWF): certifies that companies meet certain labor standards in the garment industry

Though the specifics of these standards vary by industry, they include factors like fair wages, safe working conditions, and supply chain transparency, all audited by FLOCERT. 
2.Products are produced in line with ethical and environmental standards, including supporting farmers to tackle climate change challenges.
FLOCERT: Certifies fair trade organizations and products that meet fair trade standards
Good On You: rates fashion brands on their sustainability, labor practices, and animal welfare
NOTES: Good On You is a rating system. It helps you identify which fashion brands are the “least” and “most” ethical and sustainable based on things like transparency, fair working conditions, environmental production practices, and animal welfare. Each brand gets a rating from worst (“We Avoid”) to best (“Great”). In order for brands to display the “Good On You Rated” label, they must achieve a “Good” or “Great.”

Description: ECOCERT: certifies that products meet certain organic and environmental standards
INDUSTRY: Beauty and personal care, agriculture, textiles

Description: While there are several great certifications that audit labor standards in factories (see above), there wasn’t one that ensured ethical working standards for all of the labor that’s done within homes (where some estimates say as much as 60% of production takes place, according to Nest). In fact, home-based artisan production is the second largest employer of women in developing economies, and this population has not been protected… until Nest came along.
INDUSTRY: Home goods and furnishings, consumer electronic

Description: Standards are in line with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and International Labour Organization (ILO) conventions and include things like child labor, forced labor, health and safety, discrimination, working hours, and more
This is a designation that verifies that a company's products have been produced with safe and fair labor practices.
World Fair Trade Organization (WTFO): Certifies fair trade organizations that prioritize fair wages, safe working conditions, and sustainable production practices
Worldwide Responsible Accredited Production (WRAP): certifies that factories meet certain labor standards
Products contain natural rubber that is certified as fairly traded according to social and environmental criteria.
Plant-Based Fiber Blended (Amazon developed) products are made with at least 50% plant-based content and produced in a way that restricts the use of harmful chemicals.
Responsible Wool Standard wool is from farms that support animal welfare and responsible land management practices.
U.S. Cotton Trust Protocol promotes farmers’ use of environmentally and socially responsible practices in growing more sustainable cotton.
“Contains organic (insert ingredient)”: product label that signifies the product contains organic ingredients
Natural Products Association: certifies that products meet certain natural and environmental standards
INDUSTRY: Beauty and personal care, dietary supplements

Description: Non GMO: certifies that products do not contain genetically modified organisms
Organic Content Standard (OCS): Certifies products that contain organic materials
Organic Standard Certification (OSC): Certifies products that meet organic production standards
USDA Certified “Made with Organic”: certifies that a product contains at least 70% organic ingredients
USDA Certified 100% Organic: certifies that a product contains only organic ingredients
USDA Certified Organic: certifies that a product contains at least 95% organic ingredients

The Non-GMO Project is North America’s only independent verification for products made according to best practices for GMO avoidance. Ingredient compliance is vetted by FoodChain ID. While the USDA NOP Organic certification does not allow for GMOs, they also do not test for or certify to that standard. The Non-GMO Project does not assure that a product is organic.

Certification Name: Whole Foods Market Premium Body Care
Description: Whole Foods Market Premium Body Care: certifies that personal care products meet certain standards for ingredients and labeling
Products have zero or minimal chemical pesticides or fertilizers, support animal welfare and non-genetically modified standards.
Organic Content Standard Blended products included in the program are made with at least 50% organically grown materials.
Description: Organic Content Standard 100 products are made with at least 95% organically grown materials.
MADE SAFE certifies products made without known toxic chemicals, by prohibiting substances that harm human health or the environment.

While the FDA requires products to contain less than 20 ppm of gluten in order to be labeled “gluten-free,” the GFCO requires a stricter protocol; GFCO requires a product to contain less than 10 ppm in order to be “certified gluten-free” by its standards.
"Global Recycled Standard (GRS)": Certifies products that contain recycled materials
1% For the Planet: Certifies companies that donate at least 1% of their revenue to environmental causes

A B Corp is a for-profit company that meets certain standards of social and environmental performance, accountability, and transparency as verified by a third-party certification organization called B Lab.

If you see the BCI logo on a product, it means the cotton used comes from a committed BCI Member who pays into the program and who is sourcing at least 5% of their cotton as Better Cotton to start, with a plan to be sourcing at least 50% of their cotton as Better Cotton within five years. It’s a halfway step to organic that is especially useful for farmers who can’t afford to go organic, which can take significant investment and three years to do.
NOTES:
BCI is a non-profit organization that’s encouraging a more sustainable way to source cotton through a defined set of standards. 

What gets certified? Anything made of cotton.

Description:
1.bluesign: Certifies environmentally friendly and sustainable textile production processes
2.Products are responsibly manufactured using safer chemicals and fewer resources, including less energy, in production.
3This is a certification program that verifies that a company's products have been manufactured using sustainable and environmentally friendly processes.
INDUSTRY: Textiles, chemical manufacturing, clothing, and outdoor gear

Description: Canopy: certifies that companies meet certain environmental standards related to paper products
certifies that products or practices help mitigate climate change
Climate Neutral is a certification program that helps businesses measure and offset their carbon emissions.

1.Cradle to Cradle (C2C): Certifies products that meet specific environmental and social standards throughout the entire production process
2. Products are made with safer materials and responsible processes to positively impact people and our planet. Includes Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum levels.
CERTIFIER: Cradle to Cradle Products Innovation Institute
NOTES:
The Cradle to Cradle Certified™ Product Standard focuses on the circularity of products. It looks at a product through five categories: material health, material reutilization, renewable energy and carbon management, water stewardship, and social fairness. A product receives an achievement level (Basic, Bronze, Silver, Gold, or Platinum) in each category. Its overall product label is whichever category has the lowest level (for example, if a product has a platinum in the water stewardship category but a silver in social fairness, then the overall product level is silver).

Since it’s focused primarily on circularity rather than just the ethics of production on the front end, the Cradle to Cradle process and certification could have the potential to transform the way we think about and manufacture consumer goods. Ideally, we will get to a point where everything we make, buy, and own is circular.

What gets certified? Pretty much anything can be C2C certified! Apparel, home goods, toys, furniture, cleaning supplies, building materials, and more. Check out C2C’s product registry here. C2C also has a Fashion Positive Materials Collection, which is a digital resource for C2C Certified materials used in textiles like yarn, fabrics, dyes, etc.

Description: Ethical Trading Initiative (ETI): Certifies companies that prioritize fair wages, safe working conditions, and workers' rights
NOTES:
ETI is a network. In order to be a member, companies must adhere to ETI’s Base Code, which ensures that works have freely chosen their employment, are being paid fairly, are working in safe conditions, and more. Companies are required to submit annual reports to prove compliance. ETI also works to play a key role in lobbying governments to set and enforce fair labor laws.

Who can be a member? ETI members include global companies, international trade union bodies, specialized labor rights organizations, and charities.

Description: Forest Stewardship Council (FSC): certifies that products come from responsibly managed forests
NOTES: FSC is a global not-for-profit organization that ensures that companies using timber from an FSC-certified forest meet their standards along the entire supply chain. The FSC has three different labels: FSC 100% (completely from FSC-certified well-managed forests), FSC Recycled (everything comes from recycled material), and FSC Mix (the product is from FSC-certified forests, recycled material, or controlled wood).

Description: This is a certification program that verifies that a company's wood products have been sourced from responsibly managed forests.

Certifies each step of the organic textile supply chain against strict ecological and social standards.
2.Very simply GOTS certification means that textiles are composed of a minimum of 70% organic fibers.
The Higg Index: Provides a sustainability assessment for products and companies based on environmental and social criteria
Leather Working Group certification promotes more-responsible leather production and is committed to driving positive environmental change.
NOTES:
LWG approves and/or rates (Gold, Silver, or Bronze) leather tanneries and leather traders based on how their production processes affect the environment. Audits can be done by several third parties using the same set of standards. They take into account things like waste management, energy consumption, water usage, traceability, restricted substances, and more.

What gets certified? LWG has several different categories: Approved Traders, Rated Leather Manufacturers, and Members (which are the brands using LWG approved traders and manufacturers). Here is a full list.

Description: OEKO-TEX 100: certifies that textile products meet certain environmental and social standards
which considers water waste and sludge
which also looks at substances, but incorporates more environmental factors)
This certification tests for toxic substances in leather

1.goes beyond toxic substances to ensure safe, responsible, and environmentally-friendly production processes)
2.OEKO-TEX MADE IN GREEN products are tested for harmful substances and made in safer workplaces with reduced environmental impacts.,
which is focused on the supply chain

A Plastic Bank Partner is a company that has partnered with Plastic Bank, a social enterprise that aims to reduce plastic waste in the ocean by providing incentives for people to collect and recycle plastic waste.

1.Regenerative Organic Certified (ROC): certifies that farming practices promote healthy soil, biodiversity, and social justice
2. Regenerative Organic Certified products meet standards for soil health and land management, animal welfare, and social fairness.
NOTES: Still a pretty new certification that is pilot testing, Regenerative Organic Certification goes beyond organic to be a holistic agriculture certification encompassing pasture-based animal welfare, fairness for farmers and workers, and robust requirements for soil health and land management.

Description: A rePurpose Global Partner is a company that has partnered with rePurpose Global, a social enterprise that helps businesses measure, reduce, and offset their plastic footprint.
This is a designation that verifies that a company's products have been harvested in a sustainable and environmentally friendly way
Products reduce their carbon footprint year after year and any outstanding emissions are offset.
Determines the carbon footprint of the product and associated carbon emissions are offset with reduction projects.

Certification Name: CarbonNeutral product by Climate Impact Partners
Description: Measures all the emissions created in the product’s manufacture, makes internal reductions and offsets the remainder.
Verifies the product’s carbon footprint was calculated, is continuously reduced and remaining emissions were offset.
Products remove excess air and water, which reduces the carbon footprint of shipping and packaging.
Recognizes the best of ENERGY STAR certified products with highest efficiency and maximum carbon reductions.
Products are assessed against criteria including energy use and have a reduced sustainability impact across their lifecycle. Includes Silver and Gold ratings.
Green Seal certified products have reduced climate and environmental impacts at one or more stages of their lifecycle.
Verifies product energy savings of over 10% in the use-phase compared to similar products.

Certification Name: GreenCircle Certified: Certified Environmental Facts Label
Description: Verifies product carbon footprint reduction in the raw material or manufacturing stage.
GreenCircle Certified: Life Cycle Assessment Optimized verifies reductions in product life cycle impacts through product or manufacturing improvements.
GreenCircle Certified: Recycled Content verifies a product is made of at least 50% recycled material.
Recycled Claim Standard Blended products included in the program use materials made from at least 50% recycled content.
Recycled Claim Standard 100 products use materials made from at least 95% recycled content.

Certification Name: Recycled Content Certification for Electrical and Electronic Equipment
Description: Recycled Content Certification for Electrical and Electronic Equipment products have at least 10-50% recycled content, based on product type and environmental impact.
Soil Association certifies organic products and is a Certification Body for the COSMOS-standard, which ensures products are genuine organic or natural cosmetics.
WaterSense, a voluntary label from the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), identifies products that meet criteria from the EPA for water-efficiency and performance.
Products are made with at least 50% recycled content and meet social, environmental, and chemical requirements.
Rainforest Alliance’s seal stands for more-sustainable farming methods that help improve farmer livelihoods & mitigate climate change.
Certifies furniture products based on environmental impact, health and wellness, and social responsibility criteria.
Guarantees that a product meets high environmental standards, including protecting consumers' health.
the company and their ingredient suppliers do not conduct, commission, or pay for any tests on animals for ingredients, formulations, or finished products.
ISCC PLUS certified products are created using raw materials like recycled plastics and bio-based materials, which can reduce fossil fuel consumption.
Natrue certified cosmetics are made from naturally sourced ingredients.
Nordic Swan Ecolabel certified products meet requirements on chemical usage, resource consumption, greenhouse gas emissions, and biodiversity.

OEKO-TEX STANDARD 100 requires textiles-based products to be tested against a list of 1,000+ chemicals, to avoid those which may be harmful to human health. Certification focus: #ProductSafety and #ChemicalsUsed.

Pre-owned Certified: Electronics (Amazon-developed Certification) products are inspected, cleaned, and (if applicable) repaired to excellent functional standards. Buying Pre-owned extends a product's life, reducing e-waste and raw material extraction.

Pre-owned Certified: Fashion (Amazon-developed Certification) products have been previously owned. Buying pre-owned instead of new can reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the use of fossil fuels and water, and waste to landfill.
TCO Certified identifies IT products that are independently assessed for lower environmental and social impact, safer chemicals, and circular design.
Certified products support responsible forestry, helping keep forests healthy for future generations.

Certification Name: U.S. EPA Design for the Environment
Description: Certifies disinfectants that meet the Environmental Protection Agency's strict standards for human and environmental health.

Certification Name: Women's Business Enterprise National Council (WBENC) Certification
